name: The Nature of Speed in NwN
author: calespurmarksman

posts.author: calespurmarksman
posts.content:
This began life as a fascinating discussion in the Speed Caster thread in the level 40 forum, and now merits its own thread to share the results more widely. I hope others find it as illuminating as I did.

Cheers

EDIT: per Stagmeister 15/09/20 to contextualize the discussion.


Hail all! This is a very interesting discussion!

Those who have extensive experience playing speed casters - could you shed some light on the stacking of Expeditious Retreat? The Wiki says that the spell stacks with itself. As such - can a double casting of it be similar to Mass Haste + Exp retreat? Would that maybe solve Hips dilemma of sacrificing illusion focus even? :)

Also, if Expeditious Retreat stacks, will Haste cancel its effect if applied to increase number of casts per round?

Thanks in advance!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Exp Retreat stacks, but the main problem is having the movement rate cap, unless a Monk (3rd level+ for speed)IIRC.  Also, specifically it is the Haste spell that conflicts with Exp Retreat - other sources of Haste do not (though again, there is the movement rate cap to consider).

See https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Expeditious_retreat

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Well, considering that Mass Haste is NOT Haste, it will stack (and if one has Monk Speed, it is apparent).

On WoG, I did a lot of travel experimenting with different combinations for my Monk with various speed effects.

These were my results :

1 hour = 2 minutes (180) RL

One 32x32 area

Normal

Running : 80 seconds
Haste : 50 seconds


Monk Speed (3)

Running : 70 seconds
Haste : 45 seconds
Haste+ER : 30 seconds

Max Monk Speed (34)

Running 35 seconds
Haste : 20 seconds
Haste+ER : 18 seconds

So again, if not a Monk, one is going to run (a little pun) smack into the movement speed cap.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
But the answer to the 2xER vs ER+Mass Haste, I do not really know if they are in fact that same speed.

I rather suspect that they are. 

It should be relatively easy to test imo.  Just create an area of whatever size in the Toolset, then put your Caster/Monk in it with the appropriate spells, and stopwatch the times.

posts.content:
The main problem with BBoD is that it just will not hit - ED plus an extremely high AC just makes BBoD a non-threat.  Sure, there is always a 20 followed by the save of a 1...but in this combination, the BBoD has to roll 2 20s (the first will miss due to ED) and then fail the save with a 1 (Planar Rift DC is standard 17).

It can happen, of course.  But the odds are rather low.  I have not had it happen yet (I just ignore BBoD where I play when it is summoned against me).

And even with my bad luck rolls, I have yet to be rifted by a BBoD.

posts.author: calespurmarksman
posts.content:
calespurmarksman wrote:Thanks, Web! It's a really interesting question, and something worth testing, because, while the ExpRet description in the Wiki says that "the spell has no effect if the character is already hasted", the Haste spell description does not have the corresponding note for ExpRet. In theory, that means (obviously if speed cap is removed) that casting ExpRet x2 FIRST, and THEN casting Haste should produce the same effect as casting ExpRet + Mass Haste, both speed- and casts per round-wise.

If so, considering that neither ExpRet, nor Haste belong to Enchantment school - this would mean that a speed caster CAN be an illusionist!

I will try to get to testing this in the evening - I'll report my findings - but if someome already tried this in the past, pls let me know your experience!

Cheers!
Well, people - here are the findings.

I have created a lvl 22 character (Wiz17, R2, M3), gave him ER, Haste and Mass Haste. The test scene was the arena in the Pretty Good Character creator and optimizer Module (the test arena, where you can summon any enemy to fight). I ran from one end of the arena to the other.

No speed increase of any kind - 10sec
With only haste - 6.3 sec
2x ER - 4.19 sec
ER+Mass Haste - 4.19 sec

Now to the interesting part:
2x ER + Haste - 4.9 sec (in short, consistently slower than 2x ER or ER + Mass Haste but still faster than only Haste).

Now to the VERY interesting part:
2x ER + Mass Haste - 3.7 sec!
3xER + Haste - 3.7 sec!

Further castings of ER do not improve the speed - seemingly this is the cap.

If you first cast Haste and then 2x ER - nothing happens, your speed remains at Haste level.
Same for Mass Haste if you cast it before ER.

Analysing the times relative to each other, we can observe the following:
1) the Monk speed bonus is added only ONCE after the first speed increase, not multiple times:
- normal time - 10 sec (speed = 1.1)
- 2xER or ER+Mass Haste time - 4.19 (speed = 10*1.1/4.19 = 2.625 = (1,1*1.5+0.1)*1.5 - the second addition doesn't happen).
Below you will see that this is the correct formula, because the results will be consistent in other examples. It is also evident, that Mass Haste is a multiplicative bonus (contrary to Haste, as we will see below).

2) Haste turns into an additive bonus if applied simultaneously with ER:
2xER+Haste time is 4.9sec - speed 10*1.1/4.9 = 2.25 = (1.1*1.5+0.1)+0.5.
I also ran another test to try and prove that this is so - and here's the eye opener: if you cast Haste after first casting ER you actually run SLOWER than when you cast Haste alone! Haste is 6.3 sec, whereas ER+Haste is 6.6 sec. Doing the math:
- Haste speed = 10*1.1/6.3 = 1.75 = 1.1*1.5+0.1 (here, Haste is multiplicative)
- ER + Haste speed = 10*1.1/6.6 = 1.67 = (1.1*1.5+0.1)/1.5+0.5 (it seems, that if Haste is applied as a secondary effect - its additive, not multiplicative)
Maybe its a bug, but I really see no other explanation for the numbers, and I'm certain of the stop-watch timing because I ran each number like a dozen times, and the results were consistent.

3) To reach the speed cap in fact requires 3xER + Haste or 2x ER + Mass Haste. The resulting speed is 3.0 (10*1.1/3.7 = 3.0), because of the 3.0 cap. In fact, the 2xER+Mass Haste speed is greater than 3xER + Haste speed, but they are both over the cap, so this becomes irrelevant:
- 2xER + Mass Haste: (1.1*1.5+0.1)*1.5*1.5 = 3.93
- 3xER + Haste: (1.1*1.5+0.1)*1.5+0.5=3.125

So, to sum up:
1) 2xER + Haste is not the same as ER + Mass Haste, seemingly because, while ER is a multiplicative bonus, Haste is an additive bonus when applied as a secondary effect.

2) BUT, considering the speed cap, a wizard need not know the Mass Haste spell in order to reach it! It seems, HipMaestro can still specialize in illusion and run at break-neck speeds - which is huge :)

If one is willing to sacrifice 2 additional lvl 1 spell slots for an extra ER (or lvl 2 slots if you use the extended version) - you can forego the Mass Haste spell and specialize in illusion, giving yourself 1 additional spell slot per spell lvl! In my book - that's really worth it!

Your thoughts and comments on this will be much appreciated!

Cheers!

I have tested the same spell combos on a longer stretch of ground (playground area), with normal speed running time of 18 sec.

I won't bore everyone with one more round of calculations - just to sum up:
1) Haste seems to indeed be additive when applied as a secondary effect. The exact formula eludes me however - but that's not important - the bottom line is, any combination of ER and Haste, that does not break the speed cap is automatically slower than 2xER or ER+Mass Haste.

2) I was probably wrong about the Monk Speed modifier being added only once - on longer distance the calculations were more accurate, and it indeed seems that the correct formula for ER + Mass Haste speed increase is (1.1*1.5+0.1)*1.5+0.1. So, sorry for that.

All other results still stand - you can specialize and break the speed barrier - you just need to remember to cast at least 3xER and then Haste :)

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
I did some more testing with 3 builds: M0 (Rang25/Dru5/Shif10), M3 (Wiz37/Monk3), and M40 (Monk40). I compared the speed of all builds to the base speed of M0 for an easier comparison.

Builds with less than Monk 3 have a speed cap of 1.5, builds with Monk Speed have a cap of 3 + Monk Speed bonus (3.1 for Monk3, 4.3 for Monk39).

The formula in the original post explains why EMSI(0) and EMSD(0) affect movement speed.
Final Speed = Monk Speed bonus + [Speed Increase * Initial Speed (including Monk Speed and previous speed increases)]
So for EMSI(0) on a build with Monk3, that results in: Speed = 0.1 + (1.0 * 1.1) = 1.2
For EMSI(0) on a build with Monk39, that results in: Speed = 1.3 + (1.0 * 2.3) = 3.6

The order of EMSI and Haste does matter, which is probably why the values for item property haste and effect haste were different in the first test. Haste then EMSI(0) is slower than EMSI(0) then haste.
For Haste then EMSI(0) on a build with Monk3: Speed = 0.1 + (1.0 * (0.1 + (1.5 * 1.1))) = 1.85
For EMSI(0) then Haste on a build with Monk3: Speed = 0.1 + (1.5 * (0.1 + (1.0 * 1.1))) = 1.9

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
The test module is vanilla NWN, all testing is done via chat commands so the spells are unchanged. I tested with a Wiz37/Monk3 and can confirm that ER -> Haste results in a slower time. The spell effects were correct in all cases (ie ER -> Haste resulted in the correct Haste effects and no ER effects), so this seems to be a problem with how the engine deals with movement speed.

Using 24.4s as the base time:
ER: 14.0s / 1.74
Haste: 14.0s / 1.74
ER -> Haste: 15.2s / 1.61

ER and Haste both follow the formula of: Speed = 0.1 + (1.5 * 1.1) = 1.75
A value of 1.61 for ER -> Haste could be explained with: Speed = (1.5 * 1.1) = 1.65 or Speed = 0.1 + (1.5 * 1) = 1.6 or multiple other formulae that fit this observation.

Edit: This is definitely an engine problem, I added a 0 second delay to the Haste script (everything else was identical) and ER -> Haste resulted in a time of 14.0s. So the problem is caused by removing the movement speed increase and applying haste at the same time, applying haste directly after the movement speed increase has been removed causes it to calculate movement speed accurately.

Thanks Stag!

For giving this contribution it's own home.

To summarize from Yumin's data:

- A character without a base movement speed increase hits max movement speed with just haste.

- A level 40 30 Monk or higher hits max movement speed with just haste.

- Wizard/Monk with 3 levels in Monk will have to drop 3x ER + Haste or 2x ER + Mass Haste to cap movement speed.

- Casting Haste first or having perma-haste is not as effective as casting ER, then getting haste.

Please correct me if any of the above is/becomes inaccurate.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Any build with 30+ Monk levels should hit the speed cap with just Haste, it doesn't need to be a Monk40 build.
Since the speed cap is 3 + Monk Speed bonus, if 1.5 * Initial Speed (including Monk Speed bonus) = 3 then the build is at the speed cap.
Hasted Monk30 Speed = 1.0 + (1.5 * 2.0) = 4.0, the speed cap.
Hasted Monk33 Speed = 1.1 + (1.5 * 2.1) = 4.25, capped at 4.1.
